title: How to Measure Your Waist & Belly Fat

steps.title: Stand with your feet together and belly exposed.
steps.content: Stand with your feet together and belly exposed. Take off your shoes and stand up straight with your abdomen relaxed. Slouching could throw off the measurement. For more accurate measurements, take your shirt off or wear one that’s skin-tight. [3] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Place a measuring tape around your waist in line with your navel.
steps.content: Place a measuring tape around your waist in line with your navel. Use a flexible cloth measuring tape. Place it against your skin between your lowest ribs and hip bones. It should be roughly level with your belly button. [4] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source As you wrap the measuring tape around your waist, make sure to keep it straight and parallel with the floor.

steps.title: Measure your waist just after exhaling.
steps.content: Measure your waist just after exhaling. Breathe out normally, but don’t suck in your stomach. Make sure the measuring tape is straight and without any kinks, then note your waist circumference. [5] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source If you’re measuring in inches, round to the nearest tenth of an inch. If you’re measuring in centimeters, round to the nearest centimeter. Write down your measurement if you think you might forget it.

steps.title: Interpret your measurement.
steps.content: Interpret your measurement. If you’re a man, a waist circumference over 40 inches puts you at a higher risk of developing obesity-related health conditions, such as diabetes, heart attack, or stroke. If you’re a woman and aren’t pregnant, a waist circumference over 35 inches is considered high risk. [6] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source For men, a measurement of 37.1 to 39.9 inches is considered intermediate risk. For women, intermediate risk is between 31.6 to 34.9 inches. If you’re measuring in centimeters, 94 to 101 cm indicates an intermediate risk for men, and a measurement above 102 cm is high risk. For women, 80 to 87 cm is intermediate risk, and circumferences above 88 cm are considered high risk. [7] X Research source There are no standards for waist circumference for pregnant women, children, and teenagers. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Measure your waist circumference at the navel.
steps.content: Measure your waist circumference at the navel. Stand up straight and place the measuring tape to your bare waist between your lowest ribs and hip bones. Exhale normally, then measure your waist circumference. Write the number down and label it so you don’t confuse it with your hip measurement. [9] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Measure your hips at their widest point.
steps.content: Measure your hips at their widest point. For an accurate measurement, wear a skintight article of clothing or place the measuring tape directly against your skin. Wrap the measuring tape around the widest part of your hips. This is usually around where your thighs meet your hips and the lower part of your hip bones point out to your sides. [10] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Keep the measuring tape parallel with the floor and free of any kinks or twists. Write down your hip measurement and label it so you don’t confuse it with your waist circumference.

steps.title: Take your measurements twice.
steps.content: Take your measurements twice. Since taking your waist-to-hip ratio involves multiple numbers, there’s a higher chance of making an error. Taking your measurements twice will help you ensure they’re accurate. [11] X Research source If your measurements don’t match up, measure yourself a third time and go with the measurement it matches.

steps.title: Divide your waist size by your hip size and interpret your results.
steps.content: Divide your waist size by your hip size and interpret your results. It doesn’t matter if you’re measuring in inches or centimeters, as long as both waist and hip measurements use the same unit. For men, a ratio higher than 0.95 indicates an increased risk of health issues. For women, increased risk starts at a ratio of 0.85. [12] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source For example, if you’re a man with a waist circumference of 36 inches (91 cm) and a hip circumference of 40 inches (100 cm), your ratio is 0.9, which is just below the increased risk benchmark.

steps.title: Consult your doctor if you're concerned about your measurements.
steps.content: Consult your doctor if you're concerned about your measurements. Waist circumference and waist-to-hip ratio are inexpensive and easy ways to measure belly fat. There’s a lot of evidence that they can accurately predict your risk of developing obesity-related health issues. However, they’re meant to give you a rough idea of your health. Only a medical professional can accurately diagnose obesity-related disorders. [13] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Ask your doctor about imaging scans.
steps.content: Ask your doctor about imaging scans. Imaging scans, such as a CT scan and MRI, are the most accurate ways to measure belly fat, but they’re expensive and not readily available for most people. [14] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source A DXA, or dual x-ray scan, is more affordable, but still requires a doctor’s orders. For most people, taking waist and hip measurements is the best way to estimate belly fat and to understand associated health risks.

steps.title: Get a physical exam and blood tests to assess your overall health.
steps.content: Get a physical exam and blood tests to assess your overall health. Your doctor can give you an exam and order blood tests, such as blood glucose and cholesterol tests. These assessments can help you better understand your health status and risks. [15] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Discuss ways to improve your health with your doctor, if necessary.
steps.content: Discuss ways to improve your health with your doctor, if necessary. If you’re overweight or obese, try to focus on improving your health instead of on losing weight alone. Set goals related to choosing healthy foods and getting more physical activity instead of the number of pounds or kilos you want to shed. [16] X Research source Do your best to maintain a healthy diet . That includes limiting the amount of sugar you consume (too much sugar can cause the body to start storing fat) and consuming less in general. [17] X Research source Overconsumption is one of the biggest causes of obesity. [18] X Research source . Try to get 30 minutes of exercise per day. Ask your doctor for advice about starting an exercise routine, especially if you’re not used to physical activity. Focusing on developing a healthier lifestyle can help you stick to your goals and maintain a positive mindset.
